org.gridgain.grid.spi
Interface GridSpiJsonConfigurable

All Known Subinterfaces:
GridCollisionSpi, GridCommunicationSpi, GridDeploymentSpi, GridDiscoverySpi, GridEventStorageSpi, GridFailoverSpi, GridLoadBalancingSpi, GridLocalMetricsSpi, GridSwapSpaceSpi, GridTopologySpi
All Known Implementing Classes:
GridAdaptiveLoadBalancingSpi, GridAlwaysFailoverSpi, GridAttributesTopologySpi, GridBasicTopologySpi, GridCacheCheckpointSpi, GridFifoQueueCollisionSpi, GridFileSwapSpaceSpi, GridJdbcCheckpointSpi, GridJdkLocalMetricsSpi, GridJobStealingCollisionSpi, GridJobStealingFailoverSpi, GridLocalDeploymentSpi, GridMemoryEventStorageSpi, GridMulticastDiscoverySpi, GridNeverFailoverSpi, GridNodeFilterTopologySpi, GridPriorityQueueCollisionSpi, GridRoundRobinLoadBalancingSpi, GridS3CheckpointSpi, GridSharedFsCheckpointSpi, GridSpiAdapter, GridTcpCommunicationSpi, GridTcpDiscoverySpi, GridUriDeploymentSpi, GridWeightedRandomLoadBalancingSpi
public interface GridSpiJsonConfigurable

This interface defines that an SPI instance can be configured via JSON. This interface is optional and can be extended by SPI interfaces only. Note that JSON configuration is not exclusive for an SPI and any configuration parameters can be configured via regular setters or Spring XML (in addition to or instead of JSON configuration). Note also that if property was set before the JSON configuration is invoked it will override the previously set values (and vice-versa).

The main idea behind JSON-based configuration is to provide more terse configuration via JSON rather than traditional Spring syntax.

Wiki & Forum:


Wiki
Forum

 

Method Summary
 void setJson(String json)
          Sets JSON configuration string and injects the properties defined in it into SPI instance that implements this interface.
 

Method Detail

setJson

void setJson(String json)
Sets JSON configuration string and injects the properties defined in it into SPI instance that implements this interface.

JSON specification is available at http://www.json.org. Additionally to the standard JSON there are two special properties:

  1. To specify the type of the object you can use &#64;class property specifying fully qualified class name. If type is not specified implementation will try to infer the type via reflection. If type is not specified and cannot be determined via reflection, the implementation will use HashMap for net.sf.json.JSONObject and ArrayList for net.sf.json.JSONArray.
  2. To specify element type of collection you can use &#64;elem property providing fully qualified class name. If type is not specified implementation will try to infer the type via reflection. If type is not specified and cannot be determined via reflection, the implementation will use HashMap for net.sf.json.JSONObject and ArrayList for net.sf.json.JSONArray.

This example defines one HashMap with the only key key mapped to LinkedHashMap object that will have two entries with the keys a0 and a1. The mapped values will be of type foo.bar.A which has settable property val: 

  {
      key: {
          a0: {val:'test0'},
          a1: {val:'test1'},
          @class:'java.util.LinkedHashMap',
          @elem:'foo.bar.A'
      }
  }

Note that you can see more examples on JSON configuration for specific SPI in default Spring XML configuration file ${GRIDGAIN_HOME}/config/default-spring.xml

The following example shows usage of JSON configuration in Spring XML: 

    <property name="communicationSpi">
        <bean class="org.gridgain.grid.spi.communication.tcp.GridTcpCommunicationSpi">
            <property name="json"
                value="{directBuffer: 'false', localAddress='1.2.3.4', localPort: 47100, localPortRange: 100}"/>
        </bean>
    </property>

Parameters:
json - JSON expression.
